title-group.article-title: Determinants of Bilateral Effective Tax Rates: Empirical Evidence from OECD Countries

abstract.p: This paper identifies the relevant determinants of a company's effective tax burden. Thereby, we account for bilateral aspects of corporate taxation by calculating bilateral effective tax rates as proposed by Devereux and Griffith (1999 and 2003). The empirical evidence of a large panel of nearly 8,000 bilateral effective tax rates within the OECD suggests that country size is an important determinant of the effective tax rate. In line with the literature, bilateral tax rates with small host countries exhibit a smaller overall effective tax rate, despite the fact that larger countries are more likely to reduce the tax burden by means of tax treaties at the bilateral level. Further, we find that geographically remote countries impose higher taxes, whereas economic integration tends to reduce the extent of the bilateral effective tax burden.

GDP is in 2000 prices and converted into US dollars using the exchange rate for 2000. The data are from the OECD webpage (http://www.oecd.org).
Council Directive 90/435/EEC of 23 July 1990 governs that dividends paid from a subsidiary to its parent company should be exempted from withholding taxes.

In a previous version of this paper, we tried to disentangle the effects by means of dummy variables for an investment into the EU. Due to the restricted number of countries in our sample, we cannot credibly rely on these estimates.

There are various other measures of economic integration, most notably the globalisation indices of Dreher (2006) and Lockwood and Redoano (2005). However, as these indices are not available for the full sample, we follow the literature (e.g. Grubert and Mutti, 2000; Devereux, Griffith and Klemm, 2002) and use openness to trade as a proxy for economic integration.

This approach follows Egger (2000). Alternatively, the remoteness variable could be constructed as GDP-weighted average distance, proposed by Egger and Winner (2004). However, as the coefficient for the remoteness variable then additionally measures the size and growth of geographically close neighbours, we choose the specification without weights to obtain a clearer prediction.
See Egger et al. (2006) and Davies (2004) for a survey.
See Egger et al. (2006).

It should be noted that various measures of tax burden exist. We choose the bilateral EATR and EMTR because they are commonly viewed as most suitable for forward-looking firm decisions, such as investment. See Sdrensen (2004) for an excellent survey about the measurement of the tax burden.

The OECD16 data-set covers the following countries: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Switzerland, the UK and the US. The OECD27 data-set additionally includes Canada, Czech Republic, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Japan, Korea, the Netherlands, Poland, Spain and Sweden.

Devereux, Griffith and Klemm (2002) calculate and describe measures for the domestic effective tax burden and Devereux and Griffith (1999 and 2003) introduce the bilateral effective tax rate, which is calculated and discussed in detail by the Commission of the European Communities (2001) and Yoo (2003).

The calculation of the effective tax rates is presented in detail in the appendices of Devereux and Griffith (1999 and 2003), Commission of the European Communities (2001) and Yoo (2003). A technical appendix is available from the author upon request.
The domestic tax data cover 323 observations (16 countries over 14 years and 11 additional countries over 9 years).
The exemption method is applied in Austria, Denmark, Finland, Hungary, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland.

The underlying assumption for debt financing is a loan from the parent company. Therefore, interest payments are deductible for the parent company. As the taxation of the activities of the parent company is outside the model, the bilateral tax burden for debt-financed investment cannot be decomposed. See the appendix for the splitting into home- and host-country tax burdens.

The bilateral data include the full sample of 7,998 observations: 27 home and host countries (OECD27) over 9 years, and an additional 5 years for the small sample (OECD 16) of 22 home and 16 host countries.
